reason: Step 7 calls {L_t}_{t in [0,1]} a 'Lagrangian isotopy from K (restricted to the edge region) to L_e,' but L_0 is not a smooth submanifold (it has a corner at the origin of the (x_2,y_2)-plane). A Lagrangian isotopy in the standard sense requires all L_t to be smooth Lagrangian submanifolds. What is true is: {L_t}_{t in (0,1]} is a smooth family of smooth embedded Lagrangian surfaces, and L_t -> L_0 = K in the Hausdorff topology as t -> 0. The Hamiltonian isotopy claim is valid for t in (0,1], which is what the overall proof needs (K_t smooth Lagrangian for t in (0,1], topological limit K_0 = K). The proof should state this more precisely to avoid confusion with the standard definition of Lagrangian isotopy.
